description: {"blocks":[{"key":"67ajc","text":"We recently developed adeno-associated virus (AAV) capsids to facilitate efficient and noninvasive gene transfer to the central and peripheral nervous systems. However, a detailed protocol for generating and systemically delivering novel AAV variants was not previously available. In this protocol, we describe how to produce and intravenously administer AAVs to adult mice to specifically label and/or genetically manipulate cells in the nervous system and organs, including the heart. The procedure comprises three separate stages: AAV production, intravenous delivery, and evaluation of transgene expression. The protocol spans 8 d, excluding the time required to assess gene expression, and can be readily adopted by researchers with basic molecular biology, cell culture, and animal work experience. We provide guidelines for experimental design and choice of the capsid, cargo, and viral dose appropriate for the experimental aims. The procedures outlined here are adaptable to diverse biomedical applications, from anatomical and functional mapping to gene expression, silencing, and editing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"577ge","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dklh","text":"*IMPORTANT*","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4rnpj","text":"This protocol is based on Challis et al., Nat Protoc 14: 379, published in 2019. Since that publication, we have made a number of modifications to the protocol to increase throughput or yield. With these modifications, we routinely achieve yields of \u003e5e12 vg per 150 cm dish, with a well packaging capsid (e.g. AAV9, AAV-PHP.eB, and AAV.CAP-B10). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":42,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2omig","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ehg9","text":"In Challis et al., Nat Protoc 14: 379, a Type 70 Ti rotor is used for ultracentrifugation of the AAV through a density gradient (steps 32-36). This rotor can hold 8 tubes, allowing for simultaneous purification of 8 separate AAV variants, at 1-10 plates (150 mm plates) per variant. To increase throughput, we also provide a smaller scale purification workflow with a Type 70.1 Ti rotor, which can allow for purification of 12 separate AAV variants, at 1-3 plates (150 mm plates) per variant. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":19,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b413o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5t226","text":"Significant modifications to the referenced protocol are indicated by *MODIFICATION*. Because ITRs are prone to recombination in E. coli, pAAVs should be propagated in recombination-deficient strains such as NEB Stable, Stbl3, or SURE 2 competent cells. Presence of ITRs in purified pAAV genomes can be assessed through restriction enzyme digest with SmaI (use sequence-editing and annotation software to determine the expected band sizes). Note that it is difficult to Sanger sequence through the secondary structure of ITRs68; avoid ITRs when designing sequencing primers. Alternatively, whole plasmid sequencing with Oxford Nanopore Technology (e.g. as offered through Plasmidsaurus) is able to fully sequence the ITRs. CAUTION ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b4i39","text":"AAVs are biohazardous materials and must be handled according to governmental and institutional regulations. Experiments involving AAVs were performed using biosafety level 2 practices as required by the California Institute of Technology and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"28v99","text":"CRITICAL ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bohjq","text":"The entire procedure spans 8 d, excluding pause points and the time required to evaluate transgene expression (Fig. 7a). There are no pause points between days 1 and 5; once cells have been transfected, AAVs are harvested on days 3 and 5. Plan accordingly during this time window.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"236ro","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":14,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"79emc","text":"*MODIFICATION*","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":14,"offset":28,"style":"bold"},{"length":16,"offset":88,"style":"italic"}],"key":"alvii","text":"Modifications (indicated by *MODIFICATION*) to the referenced protocol (Challis et al., Nat Protoc. 14: 379-414) can help to increase yield and/or throughput. This increased yield can be especially helpful in cases where large doses of multiple AAVs are necessary. Using these modifications, we routinely obtain yields \u003e5e12 vg per plate with well packaging capsids. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"975kv","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fujt5","text":"In the referenced protocol, a Type 70 Ti rotor is used for ultracentrifugation of the AAV through a density gradient (Steps 32-37). This rotor can hold 8 tubes, allowing for simultaneous purification of 8 separate AAV variants, at 1-8 plates (150 mm plates) per variant. To increase throughput, we also provide a smaller scale purification workflow with a Type 70.1 Ti rotor, which can allow for purification of 12 separate AAV variants, at about 1-3 plates (150 mm plates) per variant. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":99,"length":2},{"style":"sub","offset":165,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":153,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4m9mb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8eqfb","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"52os6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"6e8q0","text":"CRITICAL ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":2,"offset":136,"style":"sup"},{"length":3,"offset":188,"style":"sup"}],"key":"8b3t7","text":"For capsids that package well (i.e., AAV9, AAV-PHP.B, AAV-PHP.eB, and AAV-PHP.S), the PEI transfection protocol typically yields ≥1 × 1012 vg per 150-mm dish, as measured post purification2,3. Before starting the protocol, determine the number of dishes needed per viral prep and use Supplementary Table 2 (‘Transfection calculator’ sheet) to calculate the quantities of PEI, DPBS, and plasmid DNA required for transfection. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"D943DB70D9BE11EDA4C887FEE6E9ACA6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"37","unit":10}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"77avh","text":"CRITICAL","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6a628","text":"Cell health is critical for efficient transfection and capsid production. We do not include antibiotics in our culture media and we passage cells at least 3 times before transfecting. This is to ensure that they are healthy and free of contamination. Transfecting cells while there are antibiotics in the media may lead to cytotoxicity and lower transfection efficiency. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1bbcu","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"78u6i","text":"Deviations in doubling time may indicate cell health issues or contamination. In our hands, healthy HEK 293T cells should double every 16 hours when cultured in 10% FBS (triple every 24 hours). ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"edfve","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"6evmv","text":"CRITICAL","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3hega","text":"When passaging cells the day before transfection, care should be taken to ensure uniform cell density across the culture dish. Using a 250 mL or 500 mL tube and resuspending cells to the full volume, then plating can help to achieve uniform density (i.e. if plating 8 plates, bring total volume of cell suspension to 200 mL and plate 25 mL in each plate). Dropwise addition of high concentration cell suspensions to pre-plated media can lead to non-uniformity in cell density and poor transfection. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"81mtu","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"736vo","text":"CRITICAL","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"66lpm","text":"While expanding the number of plates, save used media bottles. These bottles are sterile and can be used during AAV harvest (Steps 18-28).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Procedure: Triple transient transfection of HEK293T cells ● Timing 1–2 h
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"12gld","text":"At the time of transfection, make the PEI + DPBS master mix and the DNA + DPBS solution for each viral prep (Reagent setup and Supplementary Table 2 from Challis et al., Nat Protoc. 14: 379-414, ‘Transfection calculator’ sheet). Using a 5- or 10-ml serological pipette, add the required volume of the PEI + DPBS master mix (e.g., ‘Transfection calculator’ cell G9) dropwise to the DNA + DPBS solution (e.g., ‘Transfection calculator’ cells E9 + E11 + E13 + F9) while gently vortexing to mix. Cap the tube and thoroughly vortex for   to mix. Allow the mixture to sit at   for 2–10 min. Add   of the transfection solution dropwise to each dish. Mix by gently pushing plate forward and backward, then side-to-side, and finally in a 'Figure 8' pattern, before returning the dishes to the cell culture incubator. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":170,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":531,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":569,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":589,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ba70j","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b7fug","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":10,"guid":"9791F760D9BF11EDA4C887FEE6E9ACA6","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"A55AC150D9C011EDB6ACFB92DA8954AD","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":32}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"9BE10630D9BF11EDA4C887FEE6E9ACA6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"3":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":13,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"9o1rb","text":"CRITICAL STEP ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":97},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":129},{"key":2,"length":1,"offset":140},{"key":3,"length":1,"offset":167}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e47cq","text":"We use a pAAV:pUCmini-iCAP-PHP:pHelper plasmid ratio of 1:4:2 based on micrograms of DNA. We use   of total DNA per 150-mm dish (  of pAAV,   of pUCmini-iCAP-PHP, and   of pHelper) (Supplementary Table 2, ‘Detailed calculations’ sheet). The plasmid ratio was optimized during the initial development of the AAV production protocol; 1:4:2 gave the best viral yields. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":3,"offset":99,"style":"sup"}],"key":"4u9cn","text":"The transfection solution will appear slightly cloudy because of the formation of DNA–PEI complexes5,6. Allowing the mixture to sit for \u003e10 min may reduce transfection efficiency. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9mbv6","text":"Mixing the PEI-DNA complexes into the media by swirling will lead to the complexes clustering in the middle of the dish and non-uniform transfection across the plate surface. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e05vb","text":"Users can opt to run a positive transfection/virus production control (e.g., pAAV-CAG-eYFP); this is especially important if using an untested rAAV genome. ","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"amount":"40","error":false,"guid":"72F51A40D9BF11EDA4C887FEE6E9ACA6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":4},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"},"1":{"data":{"amount":"5.7","error":false,"guid":"76058E90D9BF11EDA4C887FEE6E9ACA6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":4},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"},"2":{"data":{"amount":"22.8","error":false,"guid":"7937E2C0D9BF11EDA4C887FEE6E9ACA6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":4},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"},"3":{"data":{"amount":"11.4","error":false,"guid":"7BF09A20D9BF11EDA4C887FEE6E9ACA6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":4},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"}}}}}}

steps.section: Procedure: Triple transient transfection of HEK293T cells ● Timing 1–2 h
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c7tj2","text":"Change the media 12–24 h post transfection by aspirating the old media in 10% (vol/vol) bleach and replacing it with   of fresh, pre-warmed DMEM with 5% FBS (Reagent setup).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":117,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6elm4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"adbb0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b2cs9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"25","error":false,"guid":"CF6D4860D9BF11EDA4C887FEE6E9ACA6","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":13,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"1bdif","text":"CRITICAL STEP ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":1,"offset":232,"style":"sup"},{"length":2,"offset":271,"style":"sup"}],"key":"hsmv","text":"Do not allow the cells to remain without media for more than a few minutes. To protect the cells from unwanted stress, aspirate the media from five plates at a time and promptly replace it with new media. PEI is moderately cytotoxic6 and cell death of up to 20% is common71. Do not allow the media to remain unchanged for more than 24 h post transfection. Failure to change the media in a timely manner will result in poor cell health and low titers. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1skat","text":"Do not put a contaminated serological pipette back into your stock media bottle. To reduce cost and plastic waste, a 250 mL (1-4 plates) or 500 mL conical tube (5-8 plates) can be used. You will need 1 such conical tube per virus. Decant the required amount of pre-warmed media into the conical tube, and then use the same serological pipette to replace media for all plates. Keep this conical tube, as it can be used for AAV harvest (Steps 18-28). ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8j4ml","text":"Beginning 72 h post transfection, examine the cells under a fluorescence microscope to assess fluorescent protein expression, if applicable. Note that expression of the rAAV genome does not necessarily correlate with final viral yield and will depend on the reporter and/or promoter under investigation. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2ts58","text":"At this point, we switch from 10% FBS to 5% FBS. These bottles are sterile and can be used during AAV harvest (Steps 18-28).","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"21lud","text":"If time is limited, media and cells can be harvested together at 72 h or 96 h rather than 120 h, but total yields will be reduced.","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"csugl","text":"Harvest the media and cells 120 h (5 d) post-transfection. Use a cell scraper to gently scrape the cells in the media. After scraping the first dish, prop it at a 30° angle, using an empty 1.5-ml microcentrifuge tube rack for support. Scrape down the residual cells and media such that they are pooled together. Return the dish lid and scrape the next plate; prop dishes up against one another along the length of the biosafety cabinet until scraping is complete. Use a 25-ml serological pipette to collect the media and cells from each dish; transfer to the 250 mL or 500 mL conical tube used during earlier media changes. Use some of the media collected at 72 h post-transfection to wash remaining cells off each plate and combine with the scraped cell suspension.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e9kki","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"88lsb","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4pqhi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"1kpc1","text":"! Do not use the tapered end of the serological pipette; rather, create a new end by scoring and breaking the tapered end off. Slide this 3 inch piece over the end of the repeater pipette tip and turn to ensure that it is firmly attached. Gradients can be poured as described above. When pouring the 25%, 40%, and 60% steps, set the electronic controller to dispense at the lowest possible rate to minimize disruption to the gradient. Pour a practice gradient first, to ensure that your electronic repeater pipette dispenses slowly enough. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

Use fresh 10% (vol/vol) bleach to wipe the tube before proceeding with AAV purification. Viruses purified from collapsed tubes may have lower yields. ","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"82q4b","text":"Prepare the supplies for Steps 41 and 42. First, remove and save the plunger from a 10-ml syringe. Next, add   of DPBS supplemented with 0.001% of Pluronic F-68 (DPBS + 0.001% Pluornic F-68) to the barrel and allow the solution to begin dripping through the syringe filter unit and into the filter device (Fig. 8f). Last, attach a 16-gauge needle to a 5-ml syringe. {"blocks":[{"key":"2852k","text":"From the tube clamped in Step 46, collect the virus, starting just below the 40/60% interface, through the 40% layer9,10 (Fig. 8g and Supplementary Video 3, 0:00–1:30 from Challis et al., Nat Protoc. 14: 379-414). Hold the top of the OptiSeal tube with your nondominant hand; use your dominant hand to hold the needle/syringe. Use a forward-twisting motion to insert the needle ~4 mm below the 40/60% interface (i.e., where the tube just starts to curve). Use the tube removal tool in your non-dominant hand to remove the black cap from the tube to provide a hole for air entry. With the needle bevel up, use the needle/syringe to collect 4.0–4.5 ml of virus/ iodixanol from the 40/60% interface and 40% layer. Do not collect from the white protein layer at the 25/40% interface; as this interface is approached, rotate the needle bevel down and continue collecting from the 40% layer. Firmly replace the black cap before removing the needle from the tube. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":116,"length":4},{"style":"italic","offset":188,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9u6j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ccu1o","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1btg1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"l8pi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1ljn7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"safety","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"ahtuq","text":"! CAUTION ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3efip","text":"Keep your hands out of the path of the needle to prevent accidental exposure to AAVs. Failure to firmly replace the black cap before removing the needle will cause the AAV contaminated solution to flow out of the needle hole in the tube and potentially onto and out of the biosafety cabinet. Perform this step over a large beaker of fresh 10% (vol/vol) bleach (Fig. 8f). ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":13,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"14tho","text":"CRITICAL STEP ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":2,"offset":77,"style":"sup"}],"key":"2atte","text":"The virus should concentrate at the 40/60% interface and within the 40% layer10. There will not be a visible virus band, but the phenol red in the 25% and 60% layers helps to better define the 60% cushion. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ck51d","text":"Before attempting to collect virus from the density gradient, practice on an OptiSeal tube filled with water. ","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7gk3e","text":"Add the   of virus/iodixanol to the syringe barrel containing   of DPBS (prepared in Step 47) (Fig. 8h and Supplementary Video 3, 1:31–2:06 from Challis et al., Nat Protoc. 14: 379-414). Layer the virus below the DPBS by placing the needle near the bottom of the barrel and pressing on the plunger. Insert the 10-ml syringe plunger into the barrel and push the virus/DPBS mixture through the syringe filter unit and into the PES filter device (Supplementary Video 3, 2:07–2:32). Mix well using a P1000 pipette. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1kv7i","text":"AAVs adhere to hydrophobic surfaces, including plastics; use low-binding pipette tips (Reagents). ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6gjgr","text":"Use DPBS with 0.001% Pluronic-F68 for all subsequent buffer exchanges, and for the for the final storage bufffer","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"efceq","text":"Use a P200 pipette to transfer the virus from the top chamber of the PES filter device directly to a 1.6-ml screw-cap vial. Combine wash(es) with the rest of the virus in the 1.6-ml screw-cap vial and store at   .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":166,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":455,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4rba","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"66jdt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eiit7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"150-200","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":13,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"244i1","text":"CRITICAL STEP ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":351},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":472}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":136,"style":"bold"}],"key":"3dmc5","text":"PES filter devices are not sterile. Discard the filter unit and transfer the purified virus from the centrifuge tube to a 1.6-ml screw-cap vial; store at  . ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2nnnu","text":"Avoid pipetting the wash buffer on the filter itself, as this may cause the filter to break apart and result in pieces of the filter in the final product.
